author: wimcoekaerts
body:
The RPM name for centos is: 

powershell-6.0.0_alpha.8-1.x86_64-centos.7-x64.rpm

typical rpm naming for centos packages is:

example: http://mirror.centos.org/centos/7/centosplus/x86_64/Packages/kernel-plus-3.10.0-327.3.1.el7.centos.plus.x86_64.rpm

so shouldn't the rpm name be

powershell-6.0.0-alpha-8.1.el7.centos.x86-64.rpm

instead of 7-x64 (which is not standard) and -centos and not having the .el7. (which is standard for both rhel and centos)

PS /root> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value

---

PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
PSEdition                      Core
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.8
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: The RPM name is powershell-6.0.0_alpha.8-1.x86_64, our file's name has the .NET Core RID appended.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: @wimcoekaerts the added suffix is just for differentiation on our releases page (since we have individual packages for each distribution). The appended .NET Core RID would be removed if put into a repository.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: I don't like appending the RID, but my hand was forced when building packages for both Ubuntu 14.04 and 16.04, as .NET Core has a different dependency. Without proper repositories to host the packages, I had to differentiate the files somehow, and added the RID to each for consistency. Please let me know if you have a better idea; I didn't think it was right to attempt to add the 14 vs 16 information into the Debian package version (as this is usually done with a repository).

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Here's what I ran into that pushed me into having multiple Debian packages: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/1433#issuecomment-239244017

Additionally, .NET Core supplies different NuGet packages for each RID (of both managed and native code). So I can't make just one Ubuntu package :(

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: You know, I'm tempted to at least strip the architecture from the RID, as it isn't necessary. But it is the RID from .NET Core.

comments.author: wimcoekaerts
comments.body: -centos.7-x64.rpm  should be   .el7.centos.x86_64.rpm  I doubt this has to do with RID from .net core

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Yes, it is. To differentiate the packages, after they're created, the package creation script appends the .NET Core RID to the end of the package file name (for the reasons outlined above).

comments.author: wimcoekaerts
comments.body: sigh fine well i think it's ugly and non-standard. ah well.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
The alternative that I can think of would be adding the distribution information to the package metadata in a field that becomes part of the package name, but I believe this would be a more incorrect approach.

You normally differentiate distributions' packages via repositories... Which I don't have :/

FWIW the RPM package has the RID appended only to be consistent with the DEB, MSI, and ZIP packages, all of which support multiple .NET Core runtimes, but thus require separate packages. It could be removed from the RPM, but then what do we do when we need a separate packages for CentOS 6 etc.?

It's _totally_ ugly. I don't like it and would welcome a better alternative (repositories anyone?).

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: ... dang it, yes! RPM would. Got an idea like that for the DEB?

comments.author: wimcoekaerts
comments.body: for deb could consider doing this similar to ubuntu they use   0ubuntu<version> or 1ubuntu<version> etc ... could do something like     foo-version-deb8.1-   foo-version-deb7.0 etc?

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Would you do this as part of the metadata itself, version or iteration field? Specifically to differentiate Ubuntu 14.04 and 16.04 (because of an unfortunate libicu dependency).

comments.author: wimcoekaerts
comments.body: heh well i guess repositories should fix all this ;-) but anyway i guess having it in the version seems fine maybe just add -14.04 or -16.04? or something ? at least less clutter

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: It felt wrong to usurp the version for it (which is why I gave up trying to find the right metadata field, and settled on renaming the files), but it would look better! All right, I'll get the names, links, and script fixed up. Thanks @wimcoekaerts :)
